What were you thinking that led you to feel that way?
Add your thoughts here. Please write only thoughts you had at that time, not what you think about it now.
Now take a minute and ask yourself, \"What assumptions/beliefs might I have about myself or others that may have influenced how I thought and felt %1$s?\"
Assumptions

We all have basic assumptions about ourselves, whether positive or negative. These are things like “I am unloveable”, “I am safe”, “I am attractive” or “I am stupid”. These assumptions are deep core beliefs that we often don’t even realize we have about ourselves. They are general and not specific to just one situation or conversation, but they do influence the way we think in our day-to-day interactions.

For example, Mary feels vulnerable in many different situations (even in non-dangerous situations). She does not realize that this feeling comes from her core assumptions “I am easily victimized” and “I am unworthy of protection”.

Rather than a well-formed thought, core assumptions are instead more like a feeling or a general sense we have about ourselves.
What did you do and say that showed the emotions you felt?
For example, “I cried”, or “I yelled at…”
How did your behavior (the way you showed your emotions) affect other people? How did they respond to what you said and did?
How did the way you hid your emotions affect other people?
Please answer the following questions about these thoughts. No one will see your answers except you, so be as honest as you can.
You wrote that your thoughts were:
Were these thoughts mistaken? In other words, did you misunderstand or misperceive what really happened or what he/she actually meant?
I misunderstood what actually happened.
I misunderstood what he/she said.
I accurately understood what happened / what was said.
Were these thoughts based on facts, or did they stem from the mood you were in and how you were feeling at the time?
My thoughts came from the facts of the situation.
My thoughts came from my emotions/mood at the time.

Think back for a moment:

What evidence is there that these thoughts were true?

What evidence is there that these thoughts were not true?

Then ask yourself if you made any of the following thinking errors (check all that apply).
I exaggerated in my mind how bad things actually were. I blew it out of proportion.
I exaggerated in my mind how good things actually were. I made a bigger deal out it than it really deserved.
I minimized, downplayed, or ignored things as they actually were. I made a smaller deal out it than it really deserved.
I acted as if I knew for certain what was going to happen (i.e. fortune-telling).
My assumptions were overly broad and not specific to the facts of this situation.
I assumed that because it could happen, it would happen.
None of these apply.
Did you make assumptions about someone’s intentions, thoughts, or beliefs?
Yes, I reacted to what I assumed he/she was thinking or feeling. I was mind reading.
No, I reacted to what he/she actually said, did, or meant.
Were these thoughts biased?
Yes, I only paid attention to those facts that confirmed what I already believed (or what I wanted to believe).
Yes, my general opinions and views swayed or skewed how I understood the facts of this specific situation.
No, these thoughts were not biased but were instead based on facts, all the facts.
Did your thoughts come from a too-rigid perspective?
Yes, I had "black-or-white" type of thinking. I allowed for no shades of gray or nuance.
Yes, I inaccurately used words like “always”, “every”, “never”, "constantly", or other similar absolutes.
Yes, I was unfairly blaming someone else when it wasn’t actually all their fault.
Yes, I was unfairly blaming myself (personalizing it) when it wasn’t actually all my fault.
No, my thoughts were nuanced and balanced, not too rigid.
Did you have unrealistic expectations about what should be, or what shouldn’t be?
Yes, I unfairly compared myself to others and had unrealistic expectations of myself.
Yes, I had unrealistic expectations of other people.
Yes, I had unrealistic expectations of things to happen or not happen.
Yes, I believed that I needed something which actually I just really, really wanted.
Yes, I believed I deserved something which I really just needed or wanted but didn’t deserve.
No, my expectations were fair and realistic.
Think of the person who is the most emotionally healthy person you know. What is his/her name?
If %1$s had been in the situation you were in and had the same thoughts you had, would that have surprised you? Would it have been out of character for him/her?
Yes, he/she would have had very different thoughts than I did.
No, he/she probably would have had similar thoughts to mine.
Would %1$s say that your thinking was:
Rational
Irrational

Remember, this CBT process is about learning to identify errors in your thoughts and behaviors. It is possible that you could be making a thinking error right now by assuming that your thoughts were rational without testing them.\n\nAre you sure you want to skip the test?

When you had these thoughts, were you looking for information or confirmation? In other words, were you considering all of the facts of the situation, or just those that confirmed what you already believed or wanted to believe?
I was looking for confirmation of what I already believed.
I was looking for confirmation of what I wanted to believe.
I was looking for information and considering honestly all the facts of the situation.
Were your thoughts wrong? For example, did you misunderstand the situation or accidentally perceive the meaning of it incorrectly?
Yes
Probably
No
What evidence is there that your thoughts were accurate / true?
What evidence is there that your thoughts were inaccurate / untrue?
If he/she had been in the same situation or conversation you were, and had the same thoughts you had, what would you tell him/her about these thoughts?
Overall, how rational or irrational would you say your thinking was?
Completely\nirrational
Completely\nrational
It appears that your thoughts about this %1$s were probably irrational. Good job identifying the “bad apples” that got through.
It appears that your thoughts about this %1$s may have been rational. The test identified no thinking errors.
Thinking errors identified:

Having thinking errors means there is room to improve your emotional health. Let’s explore how this can happen. First, let’s try replacing your irrational thoughts with a more rational way of thinking.

You may have made thinking errors which were not identifiable by this test, but let’s suppose you didn’t. Let’s assume that your thoughts were fully rational and therefore led to a healthy emotional experience. This means the feelings of %1$s you felt in this situation %2$s likely healthy. Congratulations!
Do You Want to Improve?
But wait! What if the emotion you felt was not positive? How can it be healthy to feel negative emotions?
Let’s explore how you could have been healthier. Let’s first try replace the irrational thoughts that you had with a more rational way of thinking.
Okay, let’s move on. Let’s examine the way you expressed what you felt.
Let’s explore how you could have been healthier. Let’s first try replace the irrational thoughts that you had with a more rational way of thinking.

It appears that your thoughts about this situation were likely flawed. You were likely not thinking as rationally as you could have been. For example, it looks like you made the following thinking errors:

These types of thinking errors indicate that there is room to improve your emotional health. The shame (which you said you felt at 7/10 intensity) and anger (8/10 intensity) could have been healthier.
Do You Want to Improve?/10 intensity) and anger (8/10 intensity) could have been healthier.
Let’s explore how you could have been healthier. Let’s first try replace the irrational thoughts that you had with a more rational way of thinking.
It appears that your thoughts about this situation were likely rational and valid. We could find no thinking errors.

Keep in mind, you may have made thinking errors which were not identifiable by this test. However, let’s suppose you didn’t. Let’s assume that your thoughts were fully rational and therefore led to a healthy emotional experience. This means:
The anger you felt (which you said you felt at 7/10 intensity) in this situation was likely healthy.\nCongratulations

What if the emotion you felt was not a positive emotion? How is it healthy to feel negative emotions? If this is a question you have then click to read an explanation of how even negative emotion can be healthy.
How much do you believe these replacement thoughts? How true do they feel to you?
Take a moment and imagine yourself back in that same situation. This time however, imagine yourself thinking…
If you believed this instead, what would you have felt?
Now imagine yourself back in that same %1$s, but feeling %2$s instead. If this were the case, what would you have done or said to show or express this feeling?
How would this affect the people around you? In other words, how would they respond to what you would say and do?

You now know what you could have thought instead, and how it would have led to more emotionally healthy outcomes. Good job.\n\nBefore we move on let’s apply this new knowledge to your future. We’ve looked at what happened in the past, so now let’s have you practice in your mind a time in the future when this kind of healthier thinking will be beneficial for you. Follow these steps:
1. Find a place where you can safely close your eyes (for example, don’t do this while you’re driving).
2. With your eyes closed, see yourself in the future in a similar %1$s like the one we’ve been analyzing.
3. See yourself reacting the same way you did originally, but this time imagine yourself noticing your thinking errors before the scene ends. You recognize the bad apples and reject them.
4. Imagine yourself during that %1$s believing something like:
6. Notice how these healthier thoughts change the way you feel. You might feel a different emotion, or maybe the same one just less intensely.
7. Before you open your eyes, take a deep breath and mentally pat yourself on the back for handling the situation differently this time (at least in your imagination).

Visualizing like this in your mind is how to make imagination become reality. For example, professional athletes often practice by first envisioning themselves nailing their routine or hitting a homerun before they actually practice in reality. You can do the same. Feel free to "practice" rejecting bad apples as often as you would like.
OK. Let’s move on and test whether the way that you expressed what you felt was rational or irrational.
Finish
Summary
Completely false
Completely true
I need help!
I don’t know. I need help!

Cognition Validity Test
Replacement Thoughts Test

To go farther with our analogy of the apples, let’s imagine that you are at a local farmer’s market and you are trying to sell your homemade apple juice. An advertising sign on your table shows the price, nutrition information, and other important details that help passers by decide whether they want to do business with you or not.
In this part of the analogy:
The farmer’s market = All the people you interact with.
Selling apple juice = Your emotional transactions with them such as loving, ignoring, supporting, criticizing, caring, etc.
The juice = What you feel inside (i.e. your emotions)
The advertising sign = Your behavior (i.e. the way you show what you feel inside), which helps people decide if they want to engage with you or not.

When our behavior is emotionally healthy we call it rational. Rational behavior makes it easier for us to be loved by, cared for, and connected to others; however, irrational behavior (like a false advertising sign at the farmer’s market) makes people not want to connect to us emotionally.
It can be helpful to “quality check” your behavior (the way you displayed your emotion) to help improve your relationships.
Let’s review your behavior and look for “false advertising”.

Remember, this CBT process is about learning to identify errors in thinking and behaving. It is possible that you could be making a thinking error right now by assuming that your behaviors were rational without testing them.\n\nAre you sure you want to skip the test?
You noted that you originally felt:
When asked how you expressed this emotion you wrote:
Please answer the following questions about your words and actions. No one will see your answers except you, so be as honest as you can.
Who is the person you respect most in the whole world?
If %1$s had acted how you did, or said what you said, would you be disappointed by it?
If %1$s had acted how you did, or said what you said, would you disapprove of it?
If %1$s had acted how you did, or said what you said, would you feel embarrassed for him/her?
Were your words and actions emotionally honest? In other words, did they portray what you were actually feeling inside?
No, I over-reacted. I exaggerated what I was actually feeling. My response was bigger than it should have been.
No, I under-reacted. I buried or hid what I was actually feeling. My response was smaller than it should have been.
Yes, my words and actions accurately represented what I was feeling and were emotionally honest.
In the end, did your words and actions result in more benefit or more harm for you?
In my relationships with family, friends, boss, colleagues, and others, my words and actions resulted in:
In my physical health, mental health, and personal safety, my words and actions resulted in:
In my schooling, job, career, or other occupations, my words and actions resulted in:
In other areas not listed here, my words and actions resulted in:
More benefit
More harm
Neither
Based on the three answers above, how rational or irrational were your words and actions on the following scale?
What you said and did in this %1$s may not have been perfect, but it appears to likely be rational given the circumstance you were in.\n\nBehavioral Errors Identified:
Think back on the way people reacted to you. You wrote:
Were their words and actions rational or irrational? (If not sure, just make your best guess.)
Sounds like the way you expressed your emotion was not as rational or healthy as it could have been. For example, your responses suggested these errors:
Let’s identify what you could have done differently that may have been healthier.

Imagine yourself back in that %1$s feeling %2$s.

Although it makes sense that you felt that way, looking back we can see that the words/actions you used to show that %2$s weren’t as healthy as they could have been.

If you could go back in time and do it again, what would you do or say to more rationally express what you were feeling?
Imagine yourself back in that %1$s, but this time you are feeling %2$s instead because you believe…
If that was the case, what would you do or say to more rationally express your %1$s?
How would acting this way affect the people around you? How might they likely respond to this?
If you are correct (if they really did respond that way), would their behavior be rational or irrational?
It looks like you’re having trouble finding replacement thoughts that feel true. Try this: let’s first identify what you wish you would have felt instead. You wrote:
In this situation, what do you wish you would have felt?
Remember! A healthy emotion is not necessarily a positive emotion. Make sure the emotion you wish you would have felt accurately matches the situation.
In order to feel %1$s in this %2$s, what would you need to think and believe?

App design and wording by:
Daniel S. Felix, PhD, LMFT
daniel.felix@usd.edu

Android programming and design by:

michael.felix@gmail.com

CBT Helper is intended for use in collaboration with a licensed therapist.
Examine replacement thoughts
Continue replacement thoughts test
View replacement thoughts
Skip to behavior analysis
None
A Metaphor

Imagine that you work in an apple juice factory. Your job is to inspect the apples as they move from the truck across a conveyor belt into the juicing machine. You examine them and remove any rotten ones to prevent them from making it into the machine and souring the juice.
This is an analogy of how we can learn to “quality check” our thoughts:
The truck = situations that bring thoughts to your mind
Apples = the thoughts that cross your mind
The juice machine = the part of your brain that processes thoughts into emotions and actions

We all occasionally have thoughts cross our minds which are irrational or untrue (bad apples). If we don’t quality-check and replace these irrational thoughts then we allow them to sour our emotional health.
Let’s review your thoughts and check for any “bad apples”.
Read more about this
When is Negative Emotion Healthy?

We often think of feelings as either positive or negative. Certain emotions like happy, calm, confident, and thankful we see as positive. Other emotions like fear, sadness, and anger we see as negative because it feels good to be happy, and it feels not so good to be sad, mad, or afraid.

Positive emotions are healthy, and negative emotions are unhealthy, right? No. Unfortunately it’s not that simple. Weird as it may seem, positive emotions can sometimes be unhealthy, and negative emotions can sometimes be healthy. Consider the following as an example:

Is it healthy to feel fear and anxiety?

Yes, when tornado sirens are going off during a large thunderstorm. The fear and anxiety we feel is healthy in this situation because these feelings motivate us to be alert and aware of danger, and to get to the basement where we can minimize the potential harm of a tornado.

Would the same emotion be healthy if it were a clear blue afternoon with not a cloud in the sky and they were just testing the tornado sirens? Obviously not. And reacting to this emotion by hiding in the basement wouldn’t be rational behavior either.

Another example: When a loved one dies unexpectedly, is it healthy to feel happy? No. Emotionally healthy individuals feel sad, hurt, angry, and other negative emotions in this not-so-positive context.

Whether an emotion is healthy or unhealthy depends on how well it matches the context it’s felt in.

Even negative emotions are healthy when the thoughts that produce them appropriately match the situation."
Beliefs analysis

It’s possible that one reason you’re struggling to come up with replacement thoughts which actually feel true is this: Our thoughts are anchored in deep-seated core beliefs. These assumptions we have about ourselves are not specific to situations such as the one you are analyzing here in this entry; rather, they are broader and deeper. They influence all the situations and conversations we find ourselves in.

It’s possible that core assumptions like these may be preventing you from discovering and actually believing a healthier, more rational way of thinking.

Here’s an example of how this happens:

A woman and her husband are discussing their finances and budget. She feels rejected and disrespected during the conversation and storms off, leaving him confused about why she left so abruptly.

She recognizes later, with the help of this app, that her thinking was irrational. She now realizes she was making the thinking error “Mindreading” by assuming that she knew what he was thinking. Without evidence, she believed that he was upset with her for not making enough money.

Now that she recognizes this thinking error she wants to fix it. Instead of unfairly reading his mind, she instead wants to come up with healthier thinking for future financial conversations with him, but she’s having a hard time finding replacement thoughts that she can actually believe. For example,

She first tries to think, “He’s proud of me. He doesn’t see me as a failure at all,” but that just doesn’t feel true to her because she saw the look in his eye when he saw how much debt they still have.
So she tries to believe, “There’s nothing wrong with how much money I make.” Unfortunately this also feels untrue because sometimes they simply don’t have enough money to pay all their bills.

If we ask him he’ll tell the truth: he does not think she’s a failure, even though money is tight. He is actually proud and grateful for her hard work ethic. And he tells her this. So why is she having such a hard time believing it?

Deep down she has core assumptions about herself. She’s not fully aware that these assumptions are even there, but if she could put them into words they would be something like, “I am a failure at most things. I am destined to fail.”

Sounds harsh, doesn’t it? She hears echoes of her step-father’s voice in her head when she reflects on it, and she wonders if that’s where these deep core beliefs might come from, but that’s another story.

The point here is, without realizing it she is filtering out evidence of the truth that she has, in fact, not been a failure. She instead she finds herself looking for evidence to confirm the belief which she has assumed is true for many years, that failure is her fate. Given these core assumptions, it’s understandable why she is struggling to actually believe her replacement thoughts. They just don’t fit together.

It’s possible that the reason you are also struggling is because the replacement thoughts you want to believe just don’t fit certain assumptions you may have—certain core beliefs that you assume are true about yourself or your world.\n\nThe core beliefs and assumptions which you identified as part of this entry were:
You may need to challenge and change some of these core assumptions, but it is beyond the scope of this app to help you do so. It would likely benefit you to discuss this later with your therapist.
Would you like to continue on to analyze behavior, or go back to the main menu?
